page.title: 09Ecology:Bryanston Wildlife
page.content: The large amount of woodland means a rich & varied wildlife.Deer,foxes (a pair raised 5 cubs this year in the Hangings) & badgers can be seen. There are the usual small mammals to note; & nestboxes in the woods have been used by the less common{Dormouse. Birdlife is also a feature.The river provides nest sites for Kingfishers, now on the increase. In the reed beds have been sighted an{Attis Warbler, Reed & Sedge Warblers, Reed Buntings and Pied Wagtails. On the estate 3 pairs of Sparrow-hawk and Kestrel, 5 pairs of Tawny Owl and occasionally a Buzzard have been observed. The rarest wildlife in the area is the colony of{Greater Horseshoe Bats living in the Old Kitchen block by St Martin's. This was re-roofed recently, with a grant from central government, in order to help preserve the colony.
